23.5- Project: Power for Stockton Passenger Station [done]

The goal of this project is to properly power the Stockton Passenger Station using its own power district.

The main motivation is to remove the power linkage to the yard / mainline blocks. Shorting on the mainline still creates odd issues.

Explanation

Please read chapter "8- Stockton Station" for an explanation of how the passenger station power wiring was designed.

The short version is that this was a DC-driven design. The power for the whole station depends on the turnouts that connect it to the mainline in the East or West approach.

When the layout was converted to DCC, that design was vastly misinterpreted or at least misrepresented. The explanation was “blocks to the East for DC, blocks to the West for DCC”. Essentially that means in DCC the station is connected to the Stockton Yard or the two mainline blocks in front of it depending on the position of the T03 / T04 / T05 turnouts on the mainline or the Roundhouse T604 turnout.

Unfortunately that part of the mainline is used by Saturday operators to set up their trains. The side effect of this is that the passenger station is trivially shorted when operators short while setting up their trains or momentarily when the mainline turnouts are being thrown. When this happens, the block detection is affected as it cannot properly detect trains that are located on blocks not powered.

Ironically the design of the passenger station includes its own power feed, and has two convenient terminal positions to wire it. This is currently unused. The solution is to use it.

Details

  • Add a new NCE EB1 circuit breaker on the existing row of circuit breakers (already ordered).
    • There is some obvious benefit at placing the circuit breaker with the existing ones. Easier to wire and easier to check if activated.
  • Connect the EB1 to Booster 4. See chapter "5.4- DCC Power" for a list of booster/power districts. That would share it with the Mountain 2, Bridgeport, and SIA/DFS which have very little to none occupancy at the moment.
  • Draw a DCC bus to the Station West feed.
    • Length from circuit breakers to panel should be about 24 ft for the DCC bus.
    • I’d likely not use a relay for the DCC.
  • Align all the Passenger Station blocks to the left (East).

This would also power the 3 small spurs to the east of the station (B505, B506, B507) which are currently not connected. However I have no intention of controlling them (no block detection, no DCC turnouts).

Update 2021-01-04: This has been completed.
Details at Blog 2021-01-04 - New Power Districts for Fairfield and Stockton Station.

A dedicated EB1 circuit breaker is installed by the command station:

DCC is now provided to the Stockton Station using a dedicated power district on the “West” terminal:

The station panel can now have most blocks set on the “West” left side, with the exception of the AW one that still requires to be on the “East” right side to get the proper power routing -- not sure why exactly. Also the upper garage tracks don’t have power yet, contrary to what I expected from the schematics. The proper panel configuration should now resemble this:

I checked and as expected shorts in the Stockton Yard no longer influence the trains in the Stockton Station. The automation works unchanged.

Possible updates (low priority);

  • Dust off that panel!
  • Understand why AW needs to be powered East (right side).
  • Understand why the three garage tracks B505, B506, B507 do not have power.
  • Both of these were implied from the schematics I followed… Consequently I’d need to update schematics accordingly if they are not accurate.

23.8- Project: Power for Fairfield

The goal of this project is to properly power the Fairfield Industrial Yard using its own power district.

Power would come from a dedicated booster (see 5.4- DCC Power) directly. I would not use an NCE EB1, for this one, instead I’d use a DCC Specialties Circuit Breaker (already ordered). An NCE EB1 has been mounted with the other circuit breakers next to the command station..

On the panel, a DCC Specialties Frog Juicer is used to power the reverse section. This is why it is recommended to use a matching circuit breaker instead of the NCE EB1.

There is one wiring issue that needs to be fixed between turnouts 3 and 4 on the Y2 track. From my analysis back in 2015, this always resulted in a conflicting DCC polarity. Track feed could not be followed as it was buried under the plywood, but this needs to be understood and/or rectified. It may have to do with frog power routing of the turnouts.

Phase 1:

  • Mount an NCE EB1 next to the command station, and bring DCC to the panel to a terminal block. [done]
  • Modify the power selector:
    • Connect DCC to the “Yard Cab” input of the large power selector.
    • Disconnect the power from Block 130 or Block 110 going to the power selector.
    • This basically converts the power selector into an on/off toggle with 3 improperly labeled inputs.
    • Eventually convert the power selector into an on/off toggle.
  • There is no plan to add block detection nor DCC turnout control for this.
  • There is no plan to fix the turnouts besides their known current status. See 10- Fairfield Industrial Yard for details.
  • There is no plan to even power the turnouts at first. They would be manually set in the desired position.
  • The goal of the automation (see next project) is to use the current track as-is.

23.14- Project: Lodi Panel

Obsolete Project Description:

However since this panel is easily accessible, with more modern wiring, and ironically much less used and not as critical as other panels, it’s a good place to experiment with replacement for the problematic NCE Button Board.

As explained in chapter 15.2.5- Somewhat Correcting the NCE Button Board, the current technology choice of using the NCE Switch-8 combined with the NCE Button Board fails since, first, the board does not support the kind of rotary toggle used on this layout and, second, the Button Board / Switch-8 seem to stop cooperating after a certain elapsed time.

Experimenting with the Lodi panel would be done in the following order:

  1. Add an NCE Switch-8.
  • There are 8 turnouts on the Lodi panel.
  • 7 of them are Tortoise slow-machines, which are directly supported by the Switch-8.
  • 1 of these turnouts has a broken point and should not be used until repaired.
  • The 8th turnout uses a twin-coil (the junction with Fairfield) and is currently not powered.
  • Thus are 6 operational Tortoise turnouts that can be controlled.
  • At that point they can be used via the Pro Cab ACCY button.
  1. Add an NCE Button Board, reprogrammed either using my firmware or the one from NCE that supports non-momentary contacts. The board should first be used as-is, per specs, to see if the unresponsiveness issue arises again.
  2. If it does, an alternate idea is to replace the NCE Button Board by an Arduino Nano providing the same functionality, as described in https://www.alfray.com/trains/nce_button_board.html#h.yvp8cjti449e. I still have the one I used for that experiment, and it’s readily usable as a drop-in replacement to the Button Board:
  1. An alternate approach I started experimenting with is to use an Arduino and an RS485 interface. This can be used to simply send NCE turnout commands directly on the NCE Cab Bus, as a Pro Cab throttle does.
    Explanation can be found here:     https://www.alfray.com/trains/nce_cab_bus.html
  1. At that point, one may wonder why even bother with the NCE system. An Arduino could be used to simply send turnout control commands to the JMRI server over Wifi using the JMRI JSON protocol. It is certainly easier than using RS485 to talk to the NCE Cab Bus. The downside is that the panel would be inoperative as long as the JMRI computer has not finished booting up.
  2. Another alternate approach is to use a Digitrax DS64. One can drive up to 4 turnouts (Tortoise only), so two would be needed here. They can be configured for either twin-coils or slow-motion turnout motors. Tortoises are known to be supported; Fulgurex motors are not supported yet may marginally work (See post on Digitrax DS64 test for details).

Update 2021: The explanation above is outdated in the sense that I now know how to properly convert these panels to DCC:

  • The resolution as of 2021 is to just use NCE Switch-8 boards without any button board to control DCC turnouts. The panels are to be left in place yet become non-functional. Instead, it becomes a requirement to have a visual help indicating the DCC turnout numbers somewhere physically close to the actual turnouts.
  • Another experiment / realization in 2021 is to not use the DS64 for Fulgurex motors. The DS64 is ok for Tortoise turnout motors.

That being said, converting the Lodi panel to have DCC control of the turnouts via an NCE Switch-8 is still pretty much a task I’d like to see happen at some point. It’s low priority though compared to other projects.

Update 2020-05-24: Install Turnout Light Indicators for T151 and T160. T150 has not been equipped yet.

Update 2021-01-09: Install Turnout Light Indicator for T150.

To add the LED indicator:

  • Drill a small 3/32” hole from the top of the layout (or ⅛” but not larger).
    • It can be useful to use a larger bit like 5/32” from the bottom to enlarge the plywood passageway.
  • Prepare an assembly with a small red LED soldered with a 2.2 kΩ resistor. Wrapped in kapton tape for isolation.
  • Solder some wires at the bottom.
  • Drop the LED from the top.
  • The wires get connected to the 6-position terminal driving the Tortoise or the fulgurex.
    • One side goes to the frog (the output from the slow motor contacts).
    • The other side goes to either rail A or B as needed to trigger it when turnout is thrown.
    • LED polarity does not matter since we connect to DCC.
  • Important consideration: the LED will be in reverse voltage for half the DCC signal duration. Red LEDs can supposedly stand a large reverse voltage whereas green / orange / blue ones cannot [citation needed]. A typical design workaround is to add another diode in reverse to the LED to avoid that reverse voltage.


T150 terminal from left to right: 1 Green + 2 White = turnout control; 3 Black + 5 Red = Rails A/B; 4 Green = frog.
The status LED has wires gray+yellow, connected to the green frog + red rail.

23.16- Project: NCE AIU01 to Monitor EB1 Circuit Breakers

The layout power is split between four NCE boosters and ten NCE EB1 electronic circuit-breaker as indicated in 5.4 DCC Power.
This is a common practice on such a large layout such that a short does not affect the totality of the trackage. When operators use the layout, they can trivially identify a short by either the lack of power (duh) or by looking at the blinking light on the circuit breakers.

When remotely monitoring the automation, that doesn’t quite work though. Ideally I want the automation computer to be able to monitor and record the status of the circuit breakers.

I looked at various solutions. The “obvious” one is to use an Arduino or similar. However my design philosophy has been to try to reduce the amount of custom hardware if possible. It then occurred to me, we can simply use the same sensor cards that are already in use on the layout, namely the NCE AIU01 boards. These have 14 input sensors, are connected to the NCE cab bus, and can be polled by JMRI as sensors. The refresh rate is rather low (1-2 seconds) but that’s enough for our needs.

The AIU01 inputs are designed to monitor a pin that is grounded, typically by a relay, or a transistor.
The EB1 circuit breakers have two terminals designed to wire an external LED. The LED is on by default, and turns off when a short is detected. It does not just turn off, it blinks as the EB1 tries to repeatedly reapply power to check if the shorts has been fixed.

The idea is to power an opto-coupler using the EB1, which will in turn close an input on the AIU01.

Update 2019-09-29: First proposed version (see below).

Update 2020-02-04: I have experimented with the NCE AIU+EB1 at home. (Updated details below).

The proposed solution is to use dual-channel optocouplers to connect the EB1 LED output to the AIU inputs.

Here are the details, as updated on 2020-02-04:

  • HCPL2630/TLP2630/VO2630 dual-channel optocouplers.
  • The NCE EB1 has a 4-position terminal. Positions 3 and 4 are designed to connect an external LED. According to the EB1 doc there’s already a 300Ω resistor, and it outputs 5 V, thus around 17 mA.
  • The NCE AIU01 inputs are actually pull-ups, activated when driven to ground. This is a perfect match for the output of these optocouplers.

Details on the EB1:

  • The EB1 doc indicates a LED (-) should be on terminal pos 4 (outer side) and thus logically the (+) on the inner terminal pos 3. Contrary to what the EB1 doc says, on the EB1 I took to experiment with, Terminal 3 (inner, lower) is LED -, and Terminal 4 (outer, lower) is LED +.
  • The on-board LED and the external LED terminal are connected to a PIC 12F683 (pdf link) on Pin 7 (GP0). The on-board LED is connected between that same pin and Vdd (positive power supply) [Reminder: Vss=Ground, Vdd=+Voltage]. Thus keeping GP0 low would by default light up the LED, which seems to be the default behavior.
  • EB1 LED is ON by default (no short) ⇒ Opto output = Low ⇒ AIU bit == 1.
  • According to the EB1 doc: “300Ω 5 V”  = 17 mA.

Details for the optocouplers:

  • Toshiba TLP2630 (direct download datasheet) or Vishnay VO2630 (datasheet).
    • IF max is 20 mA. Recommended input current is 5 ~ 6.3 mA..
    • Experimentation shows that a 470Ω resistor worked well to activate the LED side of the optocoupler.
  • The optocoupler output is an open-drain. In practice that means it needs to be pulled up to Vcc, and it is grounded when activated.
    • Experimentation shows a pull-up of 1kΩ or 2.2kΩ worked well.
    • The AIU has a 10kΩ pull-up on each input. My 2.2kΩ pull-up thus goes in parallel, and makes for an equivalent 1.8kΩ resistor. At 5V, that’s 2.7 mA. The datasheet recommends the output pull-up resistor to be in the 330-4.4kΩ range and a typical sinking current of 13 mA.
  • Like the 6N137 (its single channel counterpart), the 2630 optocoupler works as an inverter, that is the output is low when the input is high.

Since the EB1 LED is on by default, the optocoupler output will be low by default, which is seen as a 1 by the AIU. My preference would be to have them reversed, that is I’d prefer the AIU input to be high by default to avoid sinking current through the optocoupler all the time.

With all this into account, the schematic is thus the following:

When there’s a short, the EB1 turns off the status LED, and thus the AIU input is read as a 0. However, being a self-reset device, the EB1 just keeps trying to re-apply power every few seconds, which makes its status LED blink briefly -- this has a nice side effect allowing for easier visual identification. Due to the NCE cab bus pathetic refresh rate for these AIU01 cards, there is a tiny possibility that each AIU read would be aligned on the time where the LED blinks, and thus the shorting status would be missed. This needs to be identified and tested first. If that’s an issue, it can be solved by just adding a capacitor on the output like I did to solve the missed button presses issue.

This is the 2630 optocoupler I plan to use (the prefix name depends on the supplier):

It’s also possible to use the 6N137 single-channel optocouplers instead, one per EB1 output to monitor.

Two EB1 are connected to each opto-coupler as follows:

  • EB1 #1 terminal 4 (outer) = LED+ ⇒ 470Ω ⇒ Opto pin 1 // pin 7 ⇒ AIU pin 1
  • EB1 #1 terminal 3 (inner) = LED- ⇒ Opto pin 2
  • EB1 #2 terminal 4 (outer) = LED+ ⇒ 470Ω ⇒ Opto pin 4 // pin 6 ⇒ AIU pin 2
  • EB1 #2 terminal 3 (inner) = LED- ⇒ Opto pin 3
  • Opto pin 8 Vcc to AIU +5V from 7805
  • Opto pin 5 GND to AIU GND

AIU01 address: 62

JMRI Address / Number = (AIU01 address - 1) * 16 + (AIU01 input - 1)

JMRI Address from 976 (62:1) up to 989 (62:14), included.

Mapping from NCE AIU to EB1 (or others):

The AIU has 2 terminals of 8 positions each (1 GND + 7 inputs). I’d like to find 7 or 8-wire ribbon cables and use that to connect a little board containing all the optocouplers to the AIU and attach them both together. I should look at old floppy or ATA ribbon cables that I have around.

Originally I was going to use AIU inputs 13 and 14 to monitor mains voltage. One for the layout mains, and the other for the DCC switch. Instantly that reminded me of the is_computer_on() API joke… since this AIU will be read by the PC that is powered by the DCC switch, there’s little point. They would always be on. Still I should wire optocoupler #7 in case I want to add 2 inputs later.

(*) EB1s for P2 Fairfield and P4 Stockton Station do not now exist, located with the other EB1s for consistency.

23.17- Project: Update Building Lights to LEDs

The current building lights were discussed above in 5.2- Building Illumination / Lights Power Supplies -- the system is composed of an antique custom power supply designed in 1997 and mostly failing to deliver 15V DC to a distribution panel. Out of the 30 possible outputs of this panel, 4 were found to be actually controlling something visible. Half of that panel is not wired and not connected to anything, and for most of the other half we don’t know where the wires go, and whether the buildings there are connected, or have functional light bulbs. In the few buildings where we can find lights, 12V bulbs are used.

The proposed update has been discussed in this blog post -- notably the issue with the cost of the system.

The summary is:

  • We’d used the Woodland Scenics “Just Plug”Lighting System:
  • We would first start with one starter kit and one starter location,
  • Then later if deemed satisfactory, we would expand to other areas of the layout.

Let’s detail this.

Starter Phase : Starter Kit + Fairfield

The hardware for the first phase would be:

  • The starter Lights & Hub Set, composed of one hub with 4 ports and 2 LEDs.
  • One pack of 2 extra LEDs.
  • One power supply brick.

Cost: MSRP is $55, slightly cheaper on ModelTrainStuff.

Without the port sharing device, we can connect 4 LEDs.

Next we identify 4 buildings we want to light up in Fairfield. If memory serves, 1 or 2 already have lights, so we can start with these and replace the current old 12V bulb by a LED.

Our first task is to:

  • Measure coverage per LED. E.g. do we want 1 LED per building, or more?
    • Keep in mind that room lighting is typically on every day, so we want the effect visible “during daylight”.
  • Do we need to black out the interior?
  • Do we need to add a diffusion material?

Our secondary task is:

  • Enumerate all buildings in Fairfield that could use some lights.
  • Compute the number of needed LEDs and deduce the number of port sharing devices we need.

Next step:

  • 1x up to 4x Port Sharing Device to connect 4 more LEDs onto 1 port + 4 extra LEDs.

Cost: MSRP is $20-ish per sharing device and its LEDs.

With one port sharing device, we can connect 7 LEDs total to that hub. With 4, we can connect up to 16 LEDs. The single power supply brick is enough to power all that and even more.

Before moving to the next phase, we’d finish adding lighting to all buildings in Fairfield that deserve it. 

Note that I never mentioned the current 15V DC building power supply. I’m rationalizing we’re not going to use it. It’s easier to power the Just Plug system using its own power brick. We actually do not foresee the need to “remote” control lights from the Stockton lighting panel.

Expansion Phase : Branchline + Stockton Town

Once we are satisfied with the Fairfield area, we can use that knowledge in other places.

On the Branchline, we have two places with light bulbs which are worth converting. Because they actually have lights, means they are conduits for wiring, and thus updating the wiring should not be too complicated:

  • On the back of the mountain, the little side building by the Smith Flat area (out of the canyon tunnel).
    • This is very easy to access from the top.
  • Next to Sonora, we have one little light stand. This may be harder to convert to LED.
  • It would be nice to have lights in both the Sonora station and some of the buildings in YouBet.
    • This may require drilling to add lights under.

Hardware needed for that is 2 light hubs (1 shared between Sonora + Smith Flat, one for YouBet). For power we have a 12 V AC aux bus in the area, or we can use 1 power supply brick + 1 expansion hub.

Stockton Town is our final target.

For that one, I figure we need 1 or 2 light hubs, and anywhere between 8 up to 16 LEDs.

2~4 LEDs would be dedicated to the main Stockton Station (probably powered by its own Port Sharing Device stuck inside the station building).

There are many shops in the town, and ideally we would add power to their lower floor / windows. I figure we budget to light up 8 of them. We would have to examine each building in more detail to get the whole picture first. We can do 2 sets of 4 buildings, one per port sharing device. I’ll leave this voluntarily open here and we can revisit once we get ready for it and have more details.

23.18- Project: Workbench with NCE PowerCab, Digitrax PR3, LokProgrammer

Our programming track sits on the workbench in the back, and is currently powered by a wired NCE Power Cab. That cab can be used by the operators to program their engines. I have an NCE USB interface to use it directly from the nearby Linux laptop with JMRI 5.

I also acquired a Digitrax PR3 a few years ago and an ESU LokProgrammer recently. Right now using them requires unplugging the NCE Power Cab, and powering the track from the Digitrax or the ESU one.

The goal is to mount them somewhere on the bench and have an easier way to toggle between them.

Hardware Needed

The current NCE Power Cab is just sitting on the bench. There’s a little UTP panel fixed on the top of the workbench that provides power and connects to the track. Since the handheld controller is the main control box, all we have is a wire going to the UTP panel.

For the Digitrax PR3 and the ESU LokProgrammer, I envision we would screw them to a little wood board, and then either mount it somewhere out of the way or leave it on the side of the workbench.

The only thing we need is a selector for the track connection. We have 2 wires to switch, and 4 possible connections, thus a simple 2P4T rotary selector (2-poles 4-throw) will do the job:

  • Inputs (2 wires each):
    • DC / analog throttle.
    • NCE Power Cab (programming track)
    • Digitrax PR3
    • LokSound Programmer
  • Output:
    • 2 wires to the programming track.

 

We already have a power strip that can accommodate the corresponding power supplies, and the computer is within a foot or two of reach. I don’t think we need anything fancy for power. We just keep them plugged in all the time using their provided power bricks -- we already turn on the power strip only when we need the programming track. We don’t need to switch on/off the power depending on which device is in use.

We’ll connect the rotary selector to a 12-position terminal block, that way the various programmers can be connected only to the terminal block, making it easier to change connections without having to solder wires directly to the rotary selector.

Here’s a simple sketch of the install and how it will all fit on the workbench:

We’ll use a terminal block, with the rotary selector connected on one side, and the electronic equipment connected on the other side. This way we don’t have to change any soldered connection on the rotary selector when we want to connect or disconnect equipment:

Software Needed

Both the Digitrax PR3 and the ESU LokProgrammer could potentially work with JMRI on Linux, but that would use only the “generic DCC” portion and thus not provide more benefit than we get with the NCE solution.

The whole point is to benefit from dedicated programming of the Digitrax or ESU decoders, and for that we need their corresponding custom software, and that’s Windows only.

That laptop I’m using next to the workbench happens to be my backup for the main automation computer, so whatever I do, I will keep the Linux part intact and fully functional.

I’d expect the PR3 and the LokSound programmer USB interface to just be a basic serial-to-USB, either a FTDI or CP2102 or similar. We would never use them both at the same time, but it would be nice if we could leave all 3 USB cables plugged in all the time. That’s going to depend on how well behaved their proprietary software is

The solution I have in mind is:

  • Plan A: Can I use their proprietary software under Linux with Wine and still have USB support?
  • Plan B: Dual-boot Linux or Windows, and use a small dedicated Windows 10 partition just for the Digitrax and LokProgrammer software.

If I can stay on Linux only, I’ll do that, as I’d rather not have to support maintaining Windows there.

This section describes the parts of the layout track that have known issues. The goal is to repair over time, depending on priorities, time, and skills. Right now the priority is to first fix anything that affects the automation, followed by anything that affects mainline running during Saturday Ops.
